title: cinema refusing use discriminatory covid
story: Cinema refusing to use discriminatory Covid passes fined £k and told to closeThe cinemas owner vowed she would take a stand against the new measures – which apply to cinemas, theatres and concert halls – calling them discriminatory and unlawful Image: MEDIA WALESByRobert Dalling:,  Dec  The owner of an independent cinema refusing to enforce coronavirus rules has been fined £, and told to close.Cinema  Co, the Swansea cinema owned by Anna Redfern, has been ordered to shut by Swansea Council and Welsh Government officials, after the venue said it would not enforce the Covid pass scheme.Ms Redfern vowed she wouldtake a standagainst the new measures – which apply to cinemas, theatres and concert halls – calling them discriminatory and unlawful.The -year-old argued that there was no such rule that applied to customers across the border in England.When the Welsh Government announced earlier this month that Covid passes would be mandatory for entry into cinemas, Ms Redfern told her Facebook followers the new rules were the final nail in the coffin of what she sees as the killing [of] the entertainment industry.The Castle Street venue has since been issued with a closure order by Swansea Council, telling the owners to shut for a maximum of  days.  Ms Redfern refused to comply with the order and defiantly re-opened the next day. She argued the action against her was unlawful and she needed to provide for her family. The council then took the case to Swansea Magistratesapos Court, in a bid to force the cinema to shut for a specied period. At a hearing on Tuesday, solicitor Lee Reynolds argued that Cinema  Co had clearly ignored the rules. He said: The reality is we say, the way these premises are being run, is asCovid simply does not exist.  The important point we rely upon, whilst it is accepted we will never be able to prove that the premises are infected, they may be infected. Businesses are given directions to minimise the risk of infection and contamination, and the way these premises are being run means they may be contaminated. This is not a theoretical risk, the officers have attended, seen the lack of signage, lack of anti-bacterial hand wash. It is a real risk instead of a theoretical one. It is based on the eye witness account of officers who have attended and can, on oath, put forward a position why these premises could be infected or contaminated due to the way they are run.  However, Ms Redfern hit back - insisting her business was safe and claimed that the action against her had been unlawful. She said: They are trying to close me down unlawfully and each time they have turned up I havenapost been there and itaposs just incorrect. I donapost believe the allegations are correct at all. Public Health Act - I have a right to run my business. All I have done is give my customers the freedom of choice whether they want to come to my business or not. The councilaposs unlawful closure is having a ripple effect on the local community. However, Ms Redfernaposs appeal for District Judge Neal Thomas to dismiss the case was rejected. He said: Iaposm satisfied the local authorityaposs application has been properly brought under the Public Health Act and I grant the application as requested. Itaposs clear from the evidence the local authority is trying to do no more than their job. To try and reduce the risk of transmission of a disease. The outcome of his ruling does not mean Ms Redfern has a criminal conviction against her name, but it does mean that the councilaposs enforcement action against her was legally correct. And as a result, it means that Cinema  Co must comply with Covid regulations - effectively meaning it will have to shut its doors, as per the councilaposs original order. Solicitor Mr Reynolds said thatCinema  Co remained open then an application for contempt of court would be made. He said those who were found to be in contempt of court can face a jail sentence. Ms Redfern was told to pay the councilaposs legal costs of £,. She declined to comment as she left court. A council spokesman said: We welcome the decision today by the district judge, which we hope will encourage the owner of Cinema  Co to carry out the necessary work to protect staff and customers. During this entire process, the Council did not want to close down this business - indeed we have provided millions of pounds of funding, help and support so businesses can operate safely during the pandemic. We want Cinema  Co open and trading, the same as the majority of businesses in Swansea and Wales, who are following the rules and are doing all they can to keep people safe. We will continue to offer support and advice to Cinema  Co to ensure those measures are in place and that they can operate safely. The coronavirus virus is still with us and signicant concerns remain about the potential impact of the new Omicron iant.The measures and regulations currently in place are vital to help slow the spread of the virus and to protect the NHS and social care.We hope Cinema  Co will comply with the court order and follow all of the Covid safety measures. title: cinema tickets shop vouchers you
story: Cinema tickets and shop vouchersyou lose weight as city picked for NHS trialWolverhampton, where a third of people are classed as physically inactive, has been chosen as the trial city for what Health Secretary Sajid Javid described as an exciting new NHS weight loss scheme involving free cinema tickets, shopping vouchers and gym passes handedNHS trial offering free cinema tickets to help people lose weightImage: Getty ImagesByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsJames Bond fans are to be offered cinema tickets and a licence to grill free healthy food in a fat loss trial.The NHS will also hand out shopping vouchers and gym passesresidents shed pounds during the programme.People will be given a fitness tracker linked to an app that will encourage them to increase their step count and eat more fruit and vegetables. The pilot could be expanded across the countryit proves to be a a success. Wolverhampton was chosen as the trial city as a third of residents are physically inactive. And just .% of adults in the city eat their five-a-day compared to an average of .% in England.Does this scheme sound like a good idea to you  Have your say in the comment section People will be able to collect points that they can also cash in for theme park ticketsthey boost their health.Health and Social Care Secretary Sajid Javid urged residents to sign up to the “exciting” programme.He said: “Taking part will help us better understand how rewards can help motivate people to make small adjustments to their lives that will have a lasting impact on their health.” The idea is the brainchild of Sir Keith Mills, the entrepreneur behind Air Miles and the Nectar loyalty scheme. People will be given wrist-worn devices that generate personalised health recommendations, such as eating more greens and decreasing their daily portion sizes. Health tech company HeadUp Systems was awarded the contract and will work with other firms to provide rewards including merchandise, discounts and gt cards. The idea is modelled on schemes such as Singapore’s National Steps Challenge. Ian Brookfield, Leader of the City of Wolverhampton Council, said it is working hard to boost health rates with innovative schemes. He added: “We are already making signicant progress in tackling physical inactivity, improving infrastructure and making environmental changes to enable people to be more active. “We are delighted to be working with the Department for Health and Social Care and HeadUp on this important pilot to see whether offering incentives can help people make positive changes to improve their health and wellbeing.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSHealth TechAir MilesAppsFitnessObesity" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: curry oscars confirms britains best
story: Curry Oscars confirms Britains best South Asian restaurants - did yours make the listThis years Oscars of the Curry World comes after the industry faced many challenges due to the Covid- pandemic and celebrated the best restaurants nominated by the publicMumtaz in Bradford was awarded Best Restaurant North East at the British Curry Awards Image: @mumtazbradford FacebookByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsThe aposCurry Oscarsapos has seen some of the UKaposs best restaurants honoured this week at the British Curry Awards. The restaurants, which are nominated by the public, were announced at the awards, held in association with Just Eat.The event, which has been dubbed the aposOscars of the Curry Worldapos by former Prime Minister David Cameron, ed for its th year and celebrated the industry. The star-studded ceremony included distinguished guests such as cricketer, Azeem Rafiq and Love Island star, Priya Gopaldas.The ceremony was held in London and hosted by actor and comedian Omid Djalili, while Bollywood star Abhishek Bachchan attended virtually to present the award for the Best Restaurant West Midlands category.  Among the winners were Mumtaz Restaurant in Bradford for Best Restaurant North East and Purple Poppadom in Cardf for Best Restaurant Wales. A full list of winners can be found below. This yearaposs ceremony comes after the industry faced many challenges due to the Covid pandemic. British Curry Awards Founder, Enam Ali MBE, said: What a year we have had – full of highs and lows as we have come out of the pandemic and had to try and rebuild our businesses after lockdowns. The support of our customers has been incredible but the challenges are still signicant.  He cited an issue with restaurants that are typically four or five stars getting knocked down for fairly minor, technical infringements and the process for reassessment can take up to six months. He added: What we are asking for is the government to require local authorities to have a much faster appeal and recertication process so that those marked down can be reassessed in - weeks, not - months. Otherwise, we will not be able to play our part in the recovery of our high streets, as this inflexible process will prove the straw that breaks the camelaposs back.” Prime Minister Boris Johnson said in a message: “I’m delighted that one of the greatest events in our gastronomic calendar, the Curry Oscars, is back in action and it is fantastic to celebrate the genius of our curry restaurateurs who have, for decades, offered their fragrant medleys. Throughout the testing times of the past two years, you’ve always responded with resolve and creativity, feeding our NHS heroes and dispatching fleets of mopeds to bring spice to the lives of millions of people at home.And now I’m glad to say customers are ing en masse and curry houses theand breadth of these islands are bustling once again, more than , of them across the whole of the United Kingdom. That’s  for every city, more in London than in Mumbai and since the British Curry Awards are now in their th year with a record number of nominations, we’re not just building back better we’re building back balti and I want to thank you all – restaurants, chefs and waiters – for blessing us with your flavoursome morsels.” for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.Andrew Kenny, UK Managing Director of Just Eat, said: It’s a great honour to once again be sponsoring the British Curry Awards. After an incredibly challenging  months, there’s never been a better time to recognise the resilient and hard-working iniduals within the restaurant and takeaway sector. Despite the many obstacles faced, from shortages in the supply chain to dficulty in recruiting skilled workers, restaurants have risen to the occasion and delivered customers a taste of normality when they needed it the most. We want to ensure that takeaway restaurants – especially in this sector which contributes so much to British culture – don’t just survive, but thrive, in today’s challenging economic climate.” The full list of winners is below:Best Restaurant London Central  City: Benares, Mayfair Best Restaurant London – Outer  Suburbs: Shampan Bromley, Bromley Best Newcomer: Mathura, Westminster Best Restaurant South East: Chez Mumtaz, St Albans Best Restaurant South West: Prithvi Restaurant, Cheltenham Best Restaurant Scotland: Dishoom, Edinburgh Best Restaurant North East: Mumtaz Restaurant, Bradford Best Restaurant North West: Asha’s, Manchester Best Restaurant East Midlands: Montaz Newmarket, Newmarket Best Restaurant West Midlands: Pushkar Restaurant, Birmingham Best Restaurant Wales: Purple Poppadom, Cardf Best Delivery Restaurant Takeaway: Maliks Express Kitchen, Gerrards Cross Most Innovative Restaurant Concept: Khai Khai Indian Restaurant, NewcastleRead MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Abhishek BachchanAzeem RafiqOmid DjaliliTakeaways" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news full-list-places-mutant-covid-"Sajid Javid: COVID rules could be reviewed in less than three weeksByKieren Williams:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsThere are now  cases of the Omicron iant of Covid in the UK, with the newest two cases having been discovered in Bolton today. Health officials in the area, said it was highly probable that the Covid iant had been discovered there, and said it is taking precautionary action against its spread. The B. . . iant, known as Omicron, was first identied in southern Africa, but has since been reported in at least  other countries but is expected to be far more widespread. Cases in the UK have been found from Glasgow, to Liverpool, Norfolk and London as the government works to try and keep the new iant from spilling out of control. See the full list of where it is in the UK below. Since its discovery the government has announced tighter restrictions, including requiring mask wearing on public transport. So far, every confirmed case in the UK has been tested and along with their contacts are isolating.  The full list of cases where the Omicron iant is across the UK: Barnet –  Bolton -  Brentwood –  Camden –  Glasgow -  Haringey –  Lanarkshire -  Liverpool –  North Norfolk –  Nottingham –  Sutton –  Wandsworth –  Westminster –  Health officials have said that it is “highly probable” that there are two more cases of the Omicron iant in Bolton. The iniduals that tested positive are said to be linked, and members of their households are being re-tested and are self-isolating. Dr Jenny Harries, Chief Executive of UKHSA, said: “We are continuing our efforts to understand the effect of this iant on transmissibility, severe disease, mortality, antibody response and vaccine efficacy. “Vaccination is critical to help us bolster our defences against this new iant – please get your first, second, third or booster jab without delay. Following the change in JCVI advice yesterday, a booster dose for everyone over  years is now recommended at a minimum of  months from your last primary course jab. Please take up this offer as soon as you are invited to protect yourself, your families and your communities.  “Please make sure to wear a mask in line with government guidance, including on public transport and in shops, to help break the chains of transmission and slow the spread of this new iant. “It is very likely that we will find more cases over the coming days as we are seeing in other countries globally and as we increase case detection through focused contact tracing. That’s why it’s critical that anyone with Covid- symptoms isolates and gets a PCR test immediately.”  All nine of Scotland’s Omicron cases can be traced back to a single event, which took place on November . First Minister Nicola Sturgeon told the Scottish Parliament that this suggested that there was community transmission already happening within the UK. She added that more cases were likely over the coming days, which could also be linked to this super-spreader event. Most of England’s cases focus in and around London.  The case in Brentwood, Essex, was linked to a local KFC branch but all staff tested negative and the fast food chain has reopened since. One of the cases in Westminster involved an inidual who left the country shortly after. Wales and Northern Ireland are yet to report a confirmed case of the new iant. news uk-news gym-owner-who-defied-covid-"Gym owner fined for keeping venue open during England’s second Covid- lockdownBySam Russell:,  Dec | commentsA gym owner who defied coronavirus restrictions by keeping a venue open during Englandaposs second national lockdown has been taken to court and fined. Police said the opening of The Ripped Gym in Harlow in Essex in November last year was a blatant breach of legislation and put peopleaposs lives at risk.In police bodycam footage, -year-old owner Michelle Meade-Wyatt told officers who attended the gym that she did not consent to any fines. She refused to provide her details and added: Iaposm a living woman and weaposre under common law. An officer warned her she would be arrested and that the matter would be dealt with under Covid- legislation. Essex Police said that after around  minutes of trying to engage with her, officers felt they had no choice but to arrest her for breaching the regulations. The force said that Meade-Wyatt, of Liverpool, admitted at Colchester Magistratesapos Court to breaching Covid- restrictions.She pleaded guilty to failing to cease carrying on a business that was restricted under the Health Protection CoronavirusRegulations , police said.She was ordered to pay fines and costs totalling £, at the hearing on November .  Assistant Chief Constable Rachel Nolan said: This case is a very clear example of a blatant breach of the legislation, which not only put peopleaposs health at risk, but at a time when infection rates were rising. She said that officers and council staff had made extensive attempts to engage with the gym owner to resolve this situation. Meade-Wyatt told the PA news agency: I stayed open because the members were committing suicide. She said she only admitted the charge after there was a slight changing of wording. Meade-Wyatt claimed that after her arrest she was held for just under  hours, and she plans to take civil action against the force. its mouth - throwing its body around like a rag doll in a fit of rage.The startling clip, which was posted to Reddit, reveals the terrying strength of these normally gentle giants, as the horse can be seen jumping around in distress before picking the sheep up by its back. The sheep can be seen laying in the long grass as the violent stallion jumps around and picks up the defenceless animal and aggressively slings its body in every which way.The sheep already looks leless as it is dropped to the floor before the horse picks it up again to throw it around once more.  A couple of startled onlookers can be seen tentatively approaching the horse in a bid to help the sheep, but decide to hang back as the furious horse is filmed bucking and throwing its head around in a display of sheer rage. As the sheep is picked up a second time its face is red with blood from its injuries. Viewers of the shocking footage remarked about the power and potential threat horses can pose when distressed. One user commented: Everyone knows to stay clear of the back end, but the front is really the most dangerous. Iaposve seen my horse lt a  lb bale of hay and causally toss it when trying to pull some lose bits of forage out.  Another added: Easy to forget how powerful horses are. Lted that sheep and threw it around like it was nothing. Others took pity on the sheep making reference to their gentle nature, used to soothe children to sleep. One comment read: I bet that sheep wishes it was jumping over a sleeping childaposs mind, being counted so that they could fall asleep. news uk-news how-tell-dference-between-omicron-"Omicron: Sajid Javid says rules could be reviewed sooner than three weeksByKelly-Ann MillsReporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsAs the world gets ready for the spread of the Omicron iant, doctors and epidemiologists are reporting that symptoms are appearing to be less severe than previous types of Covid.But with the winter already in full swing, it can be dficult to tell the dference between a cold, the flu, the Delta iant of coronavirus, or this new strain. The government is keen for anyone who shows any covid symptom to take a free PCR, which can be booked here. But many Brits have been coughing and sneezing more than usual – and there have even been reports of it being the worst cold ever so itaposs important to be able to tell the dference between the two coronavirus iants, a cold and the flu. What are the symptoms of a cold  According to the NHS, the symptoms of a cold can come on gradually, and include:A blocked or runny noseA sore throat HeadachesMuscle aches Coughs A raised temperature Pressure in your ears and face Loss of taste and smell  What are the symptoms of the flu  The NHS says flu symptoms can include:a sudden fever – a temperature of C or above an aching body feeling tired or exhausted a dry cough a sore throat a headache dficulty sleeping loss of appetite diarrhoea or tummy pain feeling sick and being sickWhat are the main Covid symptoms According to the NHS, the main coronavirus symptoms are: A high temperature A new, continuous cough A loss or change to your sense of smell or tasteMost of the above symptoms are the first that were officially recognised by the government and are still the accepted ones linked to the Delta iant.Statistics from South Africa, where the Omicron iant was first detected and sequenced, has shown that there have been no hospital admissions and no deaths from people with Omicron.Doctors also say people recover from it in just a few days after symptoms, including tiredness, headache and muscle aches, pass.  Dr Angelique Coetzee, chair of the South African Medical Association, who was one of the first people to suspect the Omicron Covid strain, has said she noticed patients at her private clinic showing symptoms that are dferent from the Delta iant.Dr Coetzee told the AFP that she alerted health officials of a clinical picture that doesnapost fit Delta on  November when seven patients showed dferent symptoms that seemed very much related to normal viral infection. She said her patients presented with extreme tiredness, mild muscle aches, scratchy throat and dry cough. Unlike the previous iants, this one doesnapost cause loss of taste or smell, she added. title: hunt bogus delivery driver who
story: Hunt for bogus delivery driver who attacked homeowner before stealing £, BentleyThe violent gang tied up the victim’s hands with cable ties and punched him in the face while making demands for cash and keys to his Bentley Continental . GT CoupeA man had his hands tied and was assaulted during a violent home robbery Image: SWNSByAdam Dutton:,  Dec | commentsPolice are hunting a bogus delivery driver caught on CCTV who tied up a man in his own home before robbing him of his £, Bentley Continental. The suspect was part of a five-strong gang who targeted the homeowner at his property in Dudley, West Midlands, between pm and pm on November . The victim had opened the door to what he believed was a delivery driver carrying a parcel and wearing a high-vis jacket. But the thug forced his way into the semi-detached property before four other men leapt from a white Transit van. They bound the victim’s hands with cable ties and punched him in the face while making demands for cash and keys to his Bentley Continental . GT Coupe. The gang also forced his we to lie face down on the floor while they searched their home for around  minutes.  West Midlands Police have now released CCTV showing the first offender approaching the house in the hope someone will recognise him. He is described as being a light skinned black man, possibly mixed race, around ft ins to ft ins tall and aged in his s or s. Despite checking road cameras officers have been able to locate the Transit van or the Bentley since the terrying robbery. It’s suspected the offenders swapped number plates on the Bentley, worth up to £, brand new, shortly after it was taken. A police spokesperson said: We’re asking anyone who was driving in the area at the time to check dash-cam footage to seethey have caught the Bentley and van on camera. Oranyone recalls seeing men changing number plates on the Bentley somewhere nearby to also get in touch. Anyone with information can contact police on , or message on Live Chat through their website quoting crime ref   . Alternatively, call the independent charity Crimestoppers anonymously on  . title: i grew up petrified aids
story: I grew up petried of Aids - the stigma from the s pandemic is still reAs we mark World Aids Day, I remember the crippling terror and shame I felt about being a gay teenager with no informed knowledge of HIV, writes Liam GilliverIn the s Aids was seen as a stark death sentence, a self-inflicted consequence of a dirty lestyle a decade of tragedy Image: Getty Images iStockphotoopinionByLiam GilliverOpinion Writer:,  Dec | commentsIn a pre-Covid world, most people in their twenties were lucky to have no anxiety around their health. Weaposre free to party, toke the occasional cig, sleep with whoever we want to, and nurse our hangovers with fast food and sleep. But for many young gay men, including myself, the fear surrounding HIV and Aids can be crippling - evenweaposre not exposing ourselves to potential infection. In the aposs, the Aids crisis, also known as the aposgay plagueapos, had the world in a panicked chokehold. It was seen as a stark death sentence, a self-inflicted consequence of a dirty lestyle a decade of tragedy. And while medical understanding has advanced by leaps and bounds - the stigma surrounding the virus still echoed on to younger generations.I was six years old when Section  was finally abolished in England and Wales. The notorious law, brought in during Thatcheraposs administration, prohibited schools from talking about homosexuality. But a decade later, at the ripe old age of , I still hadnapost received any form of LGBTQ+ sex education at secondary school or sixth form. I didnapost know that HIV was no longer the death sentence that it once was, or what aposundetectableapos meant, or why as a teen who hadnapost even had sex I was so afraid of it. Because I really was petried at times.  At school, youaposd regularly hear jokes about people being bummed and getting Aids - but no teacher attempted to correct the ignorance or debunk the myths. And for some reason, I couldnapost talk to anyone about my constant panic of dying - because the stigma surrounding the virus is still re, and education is still so poor.  In fact, according to sexual health charity Terrence Higgins Trust, the most recent estimate suggests there were , people living with HIV in the UK in . Of these, around , are undiagnosed and do not know they are HIV positive. Equally alarming,  percent of people living with HIV have never shared their status with anyone outside of their healthcare workers. Now, my experience with health anxiety is nothing compared to the thousands of people living with HIV who face discrimination on a daily basis. But it highlights how strong the reverberations of the aposs crisis are - and how important it is we begin to educate children about HIV. Today is World Aids Day - but headlines surrounding Covid continue to dominate. Perhaps because Aids is still seen as a gay comeuppance that doesnapost really affect the straight world - or maybe because the stigma is so ingrained into our society itaposs impossible to smash. But we must break through. If not, history could easily repeat itself.HIV is the name of a virus. Aids is the name for a collection of illnesses caused by this virus. HIV stands for Human Immunodeficiency Virus. ‘Immunodeficiency’ refers to the weakening of the immune system by the virus. HIV has been passed on between humans for many decades but was only identied in the early s.AIDS stands for Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome. It is a collection of illnessescaused by a virus people pick upthat makes their immune system weak . You can’t get an AIDS diagnosis unless you’re already HIV positive. In the s and early s, most people with HIV were eventually diagnosed with AIDS. Now, thanks to modern antiretroviral treatment, very few people in the UK develop serious HIV-related illnesses. The term Aids isn’t used much by UK doctors. Instead they talk about late-stage or advanced HIV. If left untreated, infection with HIV progresses through a series of stages: from flu-like seroconversion illness, through infections associated with the symptomatic stage, leading to late-stage HIV or AIDS. If someone with HIV has a detectable viral load, they can pass on HIV through blood, semen, vaginal fluid, anal mucus and breast milk. HIV is not passed on by spitting, sneezing or coughing, nor by kissing or general social contact. HIV can’t survive for very long once itaposs outside the human body. Studies have shown that a person whoaposs on effective treatment who has an undetectable viral load canapost pass on HIV. For more information, visit the Terrence Higgins Trust.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON World Aids DayPrince HarrySex educationHIV and Aids" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: i lost 3 stone 48
story: Exclusive: I lost  stone and was  hours from death - then a simple test revealed truthSandra Smith, , has spoken out ahead of World AIDS Day in the hope her experience could prevent others going through what she did after she went undiagnosed for a decade and nearly diedSandra Smith was diagnosed with HIV in  after years of missed opportunities to identy the condition Image: Andy Commins   Daily MirrorByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec  When Sandra Smith was told she was HIV positive, it was a relief to finally have some answers. In the months before her diagnosis in , the -year-old had lost three stone and was so ill that she collapsed in the hospital where she was sent for clinical assessment.It followed years of unexplained symptoms, during which time her blood was taken numerous times - but she was never tested for HIV. Ahead of World AIDS Day on December , Sandra is sharing her story in the hope it can raise awareness around testing and ensure people get the vital treatment they need sooner. Despite experiencing a number of chest infections and symptoms linked with HIV - such as unexplained night sweats, weight loss, coldsores and thrush for  years - she said medics never even considered the virus. She believes that because of her age, location and not falling into a group with a high prevalence of HIV, medics overlooked the possibility that she could have the illness.  It wasnapost until July , after being sent to hospital in Harrogate that Sandra, from North Yorkshire, was finally given the answer she needed. The doctor told me that I was HIV positive, she recalled. I thought he was going to say stage four cancer. It was a relief to know what it was. By that stage her condition was so advanced that medics said she needed immediate urgent treatment at St Jamesapos University in Leeds to save her le. I was pretty far gone, I was at the stage where it was goodbye, Sandra said. They said that within  hours it would be critical. I was in hospital for the whole of August , they saved my le.  Sandra said: I donapost know whether they discarded the idea that I had it, or just didnapost think of it at all. I just hope one or two of them went home and had a couple of nightmares. If anyone had said to letaposs do an HIV test Iaposd have said yes, by all means. An earlier diagnosis would have made a huge dference. If I had stayed at home, I live on my own, trying to live with this illness I could have died. I just donapost know why I wasnapost tested. Because of the weight loss I wonderedit was cancer that was being missed. She said she hopes her experience encourages medics to ensure patients are checked for HIV. Sandra said: Iaposve lived in fear that I was going to slip through the net. Iaposm an example of what can happen, but I donapost want this to be a sob story about me. I want to show that GPs should test for everything, itaposs only a simple blood test.  Sandra, who believes she had been HIV positive for  years before it was diagnosed, is now able to manage her condition through medication - although she said the amount of tablets she takes is higher than it would beshe had been diagnosed early. I donapost feel like Iaposm fading away, which is how I felt before, she said. Recent highly acclaimed TV drama Itaposs A Sin, which tackled the emergence of the AIDS epidemic in the s, was a hard watch, Sandra said. It shows people dying from AIDS, it was like a blow to the head because to me thataposs how I was when I went into St Jamesapos. It was only then that I realised Iaposd been living with it all through  and years and years prior to it.Sandra now volunteers with HiVitality, a charity which provides retreats for people with the condition to spent time with others in the same position.There are people out there that need reaching and need help, this is something that they need, she said. Charity the Terrence Higgins Trust, which provides support for people with HIV, said that the delay in identying Sandraaposs condition shouldnapost have happened, and said she was not tested until it was nearly too late. It is campaigning for opt-out testing at AE departments - meaning blood taken from patients is tested for HIV unless they say no - a move Sandra said she agrees with. Liz Porter, clinical director at the Terrence Higgins Trust, said: Sandra’s story is such a sad one and it absolutely shouldn’t have happened. Sandra was presenting with a lot of the indicators of undiagnosed HIV, including unexplained weight loss, coldsores and thrush, and yet no one thought to test her until it was almost too late. Sandra’s is an extreme and rare example of incredibly late diagnosis, but the latest data shows that % of people diagnosed with HIV are still being diagnosed late. Which means the diagnosis comes after damage to the immune system has already begun. This is worst in those aged  and over where a shocking % of people are diagnosed late. Too often both iniduals and health professionals don’t think of HIV affecting certain groups, for example a white woman in her s like Sandra. Ms Porter said that routine testing in Sandraaposs area could have made. a big dference and avoided the health problems she is now experiencing. She stated: Routine testing across healthcare is a clear way to avoid this happening to others, alongside educating professionals about HIV and what indicator conditions to look out for. If routine testing had been in place where Sandra lives, she would have been diagnosed years earlier with a simple test at her GP and avoided the health problems she is now experiencing. It would also have saved the NHS money and avoided Sandra’s weeks in hospital. You can live a long, healthy le with HIV thanks to treatment – but the earlier you’re diagnosed, the better. title: londoners criticise sparse trafalgar square
story: Londoners criticise sparse Trafalgar Square Christmas tree calling it flea bittenEvery year since , a  metre tall tree gets shipped from Oslo to London as a sign of gratitude for Britains support during World War IILondoners do not appear to be impressed with the display Image: PAByLea Dza SeebergAlice Peacock:,  Dec | commentsThe Trafalgar Square Christmas tree has been criticised by underwhelmed Londoners who have described it as looking “flea bitten” and asked“the rest is stuck in customs”. The Christmas tree in London’s Trafalgar Square is one of London’s most iconic displays and has a long history attached to it. Every year since , a  metre tall tree gets shipped from Oslo to London as a sign of gratitude for Britainaposs support during World War II. Itaposs felled in Oslo in a ceremony attended by the Lord Mayor of Westminster, the British ambassador to Norway, and the Mayor of Oslo, then shipped to London by sea and decorated in Trafalgar Square in traditional Norwegian fashion. It is currently being decorated and is set to be lit on December . But this year, Londoners are underwhelmed with the tree, which appears to be a little scant on both branches and pine needles in its middle section.One passerby shared a photo of the tree to Twitter and the reactions soon started pouring in, with many left unimpressed.Does it get dressed with extra branches or is that it  asked one person, referring to the tree looking sparse. “Interflora clearly forgot to include the little sachet of plant feed,” one user quipped. The comment prompted Interflora’s official account to pipe up, commenting: “Our sachets are amazing, but not sure even theyaposd do the trick here...! Have we fallen out with Norway ! another person said, while a fourth person asked jokingly Did it get delivered by Hermes  Dear me, thataposs a bit flea bitten, complained another user.  Where’s the rest of it  It’s Gonna need a lot of tinsel to jazz that up! another person wrote. But others were quick to jump to the treeaposs defence. One Twitter user wrote: I was there  weeks ago for the tree felling ceremony, a very proud moment for me but also Norway. We must always remember why this happens, also you’d probably need to drop out a little on one sideyou weighed several tons and had a two week journey. It’s Christmas people. Another said I think that’s just how that age of tree is. Should look finethey garland the lights on it in a scalloping pattern, rather than the taut vertical lines they did last year which accentuated it’s slenderness. A very nice gt and a good tradition. The so-called “official” Trafalgar Tree account eventually chimed in, commenting: “Over  comments about ME”.“Is it fair to say I am possibly the most famous tree in the world! #HatersGonnaHate #ChristmasSpirit ,” they commented.Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON World War Christmas trees" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: love actually london filming locations
story: The Love Actually London filming locations - and how to visit this ChristmasThe  Christmas movie is high up on many peoples favourite festive films list, and for anyone visiting London for the holidays, this self-guided tour is a mustThe iconic Love Actually cards scene was filmed in Notting Hill Image: UNIVERSALByBethan ShufflebothamNiche Writer:,  Dec | commentsFestive rom-com Love Actually is top of many peopleaposs Christmas film favourites. The  movie features an all-star ensemble cast from Emma Thompson and Keira Knightley, to Colin Firth and Hugh Grant - not forgetting the late, great Alan Rickman. For those unfamiliar with the plot, it follows  dferent stories, delving into ying aspects of love as each of the relationships are somewhat interlinked. But it’s not just the actors that dazzle on set - in fact, London looks simply stunning lit up for the holidays as the film takes place in ious locations around the city. Right now, you’d feature around half-way through the film, as it’s set five weeks before Christmas, played out in a countdown to December . That means it’s the perfect time to hit the Big Smoke and visit some of the stunning set locations where the festive favourite was filmed. Soyou want to pretend you’re a fly on the wall at Juliet’s house while Mark declares his love with cards, or recreate the scene where Sam runs after Joanna in the airport, here are some of the locations you could visit. Heathrow Airport  Hugh Grant’s iconic voiceover opens the movie at Heathrow Airport - which is where the film ends, too. Playing the Prime Minister, he says: “Whenever I get gloomy with the state of the world, I think about the arrivals gate at Heathrow Airport. General opinion’s starting to make out that we live in a world of hatred and greed, but I don’t see that. It seems to me that love is everywhere... “When the planes hit the Twin Towers, as far as I know, none of the phone calls from the people on board were messages of hate or revenge – they were all messages of love. If you look for it, I’ve got a sneaky feeling you’ll find that love actually is all around.” It sets the fuzzy, warm tone of the holiday movie, as hidden cameras in Heathrow’s Terminal  captured real-le emotional reunions in the arrivals hall, with the people featured then asked for permission to use the clips. Selfridges  On busy Oxford Street, it was at the department store Selfridges where Alan Rickman, as Harry, purchased a necklace for a woman who wasn’t his we, Karen . He buys the gt for a colleague named Mia, with a shopping assistantwho makes the gt wrapping process a painstaking one for Harry. Somerset House  The central court of Somerset House, in The Strand, is where the skating rink in the opening montage was filmed. Formerly a parking lot, the court is now home to  fountains in summer, and the ice rink in winter, which is open to the public.If you fancy pretending you’re an extra in the scene, you canbook ticketsto the rink from £ per person.Notting Hill  Notting Hill features in Love Actually not once, but twice. First it’s home to the recording studio where Billyrecords his cheesy Christmas song at Westway Studios. But we see the popular neighbourhood again, at St Luke’s Mews where Mark professes his love to Juliet in that iconic cards scene. The unmistakable cobbled streets and coloured properties make for a beautul filming location, made all the more stunning by the festive lights. Queen’s Walk  If you’re a London regular, you’ve probably taken it walk along the south bank of the River Thames numerous times. It’s on these benches where Liam Neeson’s character, Daniel, has an emotional heart-to-heart with his son, where he discovers he’s not just distracted, he’s in love, actually. To be even more precise, the bench is on Gabriel’s Wharf, in front of the Riviera Restaurant. Wondering where to eat, drink or visit for your next UK holiday  At Chill we help you decide where to go and stay next with hundreds of recommendations right on your doorstep. Visit our brilliant new website chill and start packing. If youaposd also like weekly inspiration and advice for your next trip, you can sign up to the Chill newsletter here. For the latest must-have travel news follow us on Instagram, Facebook and Twitter. St Paul’s Church St Paul’s Church, in Clapham, is one of the venues you might need a packet of tissues for. Filmed at this th century church, in South London, Love Actually saw Daniel bury his we in a tear-jerking scene. It’s also the church - which is Grade II* listed - where Peter marries Juliet to ‘All You Need is Love’. Where  can you visit Love Actually filming locations  Whether you’re a fan of the film or not, Trafalgar Square is well worth a visit to see the huge Christmas tree - a traditional gt from Norway. And while the scenes set at  Downing Street were filmed at Shepperton Studios, you could always take a trip to see the landmark which was ‘home’ to Hugh Grant. Other notable filming locations in the festive film include Grosvenor Chapel, Millennium Bridge, Marble Arch and the OXO Tower, as well as Elliott School in Pullman Gardens where the Christmas concert was filmed. title: meghan markle prince harry given
story: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry given nudge over £m Spoty deal after just one showPrince Harry and Meghan Markle were expected to put out a series of podcasts throughout  - but none have materialised and theyve reportedly been given a nudgeHarry and Meghan are said to be trying to roll out new episodes Image: PAByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsPrince Harry and Meghan Markle are fighting to protect an £m deal with Spoty to produce a series of podcasts, after only creating one episode in a year.The streaming  announced last year that it would host a full-scale launch of from the couple throughout  - but nothing has materialised since the  festive holiday.Now Spoty bosses are said to have given the Duke and Duchess of Sussex a gentle nudge to follow up from their -minute special episode last December, The Sun reports.The pair found time to take part in a number of other broadcast shows, including Harryaposs appearances on Dax Shepherdaposs Armchair Expert in May, Meghanaposs involvement in the Ellen DeGeneres show earlier this month, and not forgetting their exclusive interview with Oprah Winfrey in March. After realising that the deal so far had cost them £, a minute, Spoty has reportedly been left mystied as to why the couple have not produced any content, according to The Sun.  The music and podcast service is said to have contacted their pairaposs Archewell Audio brand to ensure they protect the future of the multimillion-pound contract. One source told the newspaper: “Spoty were delighted when they signed the couple, but the lack of content has mystied them. Particularly as they seem to have no problem producing content for other s.” After hiring veteran podcast producer, Rebecca Sanaes, the couple are believed to be releasing a whole set of new episodes in time for this Christmas.  Another source said: “When Harry and Meghan signed the Spoty deal in December, they didn’t really have a full audio team behind them, there were no scripts ready and they hadn’t made podcasts before. The holiday special episode was whacked together but, even though it was well received by fans, it was hard for them to pull off.” Harry and Meghan began looking for commercial deals after they were cut off by the Princeaposs family following their decision to break away from all Royal duties. The pair now live in a £million mansion in Montecito, Calornia.Angela Levin, Prince Harry ’s biographer, said: “Harry and Meghan want to do too many things at the same time.” Legal experts say Harry and Meghan will need to meet any deadlines stipulated in their contract to secure the funds. Alex Cook, Partner at Helix Law, a specialist litigation firm of solicitors, added: It might be considered embarrassing for Harry, Megan and Spoty equally to air any dispute publicly and it wouldn’t be surprisingthere are private commercial arbitration clauses to manage any disputes between them all. Archewell Audio was approached for comment while Spoty said last night: “Big things are coming. Stay tuned.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON SpotyPrince HarryMeghan Markle" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: picture electric car parked pavement
story: Picture of electric car parked on pavement sparks fierce charging point debatePeople have been accused of electric vehicle shaming but many agreed the person was selfish for parking up on the pavement to charge the BMW with the cable stretching over the front gardenThe BMW was parked on the pavement in Cardf while the vehicle was being charged-up Image: TwitterByReem AhmedSam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Dec | comments An image of an electric car being charged-up on a pavement has caused a big stir online. The picture was uploaded to facebook after a resident in Cardf, Wales, spotted the electric BMW while on a walk, reports WalesOnline.A cable can be seen stretching from the home over the front garden of the property, connecting to the charging point of the car. It has sparked a big debate online about the practicality of electric vehicles - and the loss of pedestrianised spaces. The dad who uploaded the photo said a big re-think is needed. He captioned the post: Genuinely staggered to come across this on a walk with the baby. Since the s we’ve given so much space over to petrol cars.  We can’t allow the small pockets left for people to be given over to electric cars. But things didnapost end there, with more people chipping in with their views on the subject. One responded: This just wonapost do. Itaposs obstructing the footway with a vehicle – its mode of propulsion does not change that. That was echoed by another user, who said: You donapost get to block the pavement with your private property, go and charge it somewhere . Other agreed saying the car owner was being selfish. If you want to connect to the house give up your garden donapost ask me to give up the footpath, said a third before adding: I would be tempted to walk over that.  But not everyone saw eye-to-eye on the debate. One person posted: How about you finding an issue where there isn’t one  Plenty of room to get past, they’re just trying to create the safest situation they can. Would you prefer a long cable draped across to the road  Because that’s their other choice here. Find something real to get annoyed about. Another fumed: EV [electric vehicle] shaming - I get itaposs annoying, but that is a pretty wide pavement. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  I notice the car deliberately parked very close to wall to give max space on other side and to avoid a trip hazard cable.Earlier this month, in a speech to the Confederation of British Industry , Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced new legislation that will require new homes in England to have electric vehicle charging points installed from .Supermarkets and workplaces will also be required to have the charging points installed as well as homes undergoing major renovations. The government has already announced that the sale of new petrol and diesel cars will end in the UK in  and it is hoped the new laws will mean up to , new charging points will be made available every year. news uk-news prince-harry-stars-narrator-brand-"Prince Harry and Winnie Byanyima call for a peoples vaccineByKieren Williams:,  Dec | commentsThe Duke of Sussex has narrated a new video to mark World Aids Day.In the new video, Prince Harry highlights the parallels between the struggles for access to HIV medicines and inequality surrounding the rollout of the Covid vaccines and boosters.He co-voices the footage with UNAIDS executive director Winnie Byanyima. The video is a part of a project for The People’s Vaccine Alliance as part of a World Health Organisation and UNAIDS event. Harry said: There are striking parallels between Covid- and another deadly pandemic. One that emerged  years ago - HIV. The video also features clips of Prince Harry’s mother, Diana, Princess of Wales, meeting Aids patients.  The Duke of Sussex added: This is a story about how corporate greed and political failure have prolonged both pandemics and what we can do to stop it. By ending vaccine monopolies and sharing technology, companies in the developing world can start producing Covid vaccines too...Break the monopolies...deliver a Peopleaposs Vaccine. Alongside the video, Prince Harry also wrote a letter to WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus and Ms Byanyima. In it he wrote how “deeply grateful” his mother, who was known for helping to break stigma around HIV and Aids, would have been for their achievements. The letter was read out by the WHOaposs director of global HIV, hepatitis and STIs programmes Dr Meg Doherty at the event. Harry wrote: On this World Aids Day we recognise the  years that have shaped le for many.  We honour those whose lives have been cut short and reaffirm our commitment to a scientic community that has worked tirelessly against this disease. My mother would be deeply grateful for everything you stand for and have accomplished. We all share that gratitude, so thank you. In sharp comparison he called the rollout of the Covid vaccine globally a “spectacular failure”. The Prince called vaccinating the world a test of “our moral character” and said the world was failing.  He said: Similar to the Aids crisis, weaposve yet again revealed over the past year that the value of le depends on whether you were born and or live in a rich nation, or a developing country. Now more than ever, the voiceless majority of the world needs to be heard and the onus is on our leaders to end this pandemic.” He warned that repeating failures that surrounded and worsened the Aids epidemic would be a “betrayal of the next generation”. He called on world leaders to learn lessons from the past “where millions died unnecessarily” due to unequal access to treatment. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  He said: Are we really comfortable repeating the failures of the past  Everything Iaposve learnt, from the youth of Sentebale, tells me not. They see how repeating these mistakes is destructive and self-defeating, it is a betrayal of the next generation. Letaposs spend today celebrating and building on the work of champions who turned what was once a death sentence into a manageable condition. Letaposs spend tomorrow continuing our efforts to save lives and make a dference. news uk-news queen-finds-distance-between-herself-"Queen: We should not be too worried about health says expertByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Dec | commentsThe Queen finds it dficult that she has been unable to see Prince Harry and Meghan Markle ’s children, a royal expert has claimed.Her Majesty has not seen great-grandson Archie since  and is yet to meet Lilibet, who was born in the United States in June.It’s unclear when Harry and Meghan will bothto the UK with their children, with some tipping them to come to Britain for the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee next year.And speaking in the Channel  documentary : The Queen’s Terrible Year, royal expert Camilla Tominey says it has been hard for the Queen to be so far away from her two great-grandchildren.  She said: Iaposm sure the Queen was absolutely delighted to hear the news that the Sussexes were expecting a second child. She continued: But it is dficult for the Queen. She has not been able to see Archie. I think the last time she was able to see Archie in the flesh was November . The only way the Queen will be able to see these children isthey come over to the UK. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. Maybe she will see them next year when she marks her Platinum Jubilee. We have to wait and see.Last week it was reported that the Queen waslooking forward to Christmasandher traditional family festive get togetherat her Norfolk estate of Sandringham. It is understood the Queen will travel to Sandringham on or around Friday, December .Christmas guests will includePrince Charlesand theDuchess of Cornwallas well as Prince William, theDuchess of Cambridgeand their three children. But one report has claimed Harry and Meghannot be coming to the UKto jointhe Queenfor her first Christmas without the latePrince Philip .The couple had reportedly been invited to join the rest of the royals at Sandringham for Christmas.  But a source toldPage Six: “There’s a lot that goes into the logistics and the planning of the family Christmas, so of course, staff know that Harry and Meghan are not coming.“If they were, they would have communicated it to their family by now. “But this is Her Majesty’s first Christmas without her husband, so one would have hoped they would want to be with her.” The Sussexes have not commented on the claims. news uk-news queen-once-served-builder-cup-"Queen wanted to set example at Christmas says expertByKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsAn oblivious builder had an unfortunate encounter with the Queen when he told her he didnapost want any of that nonsense I had last time when she offered him a cup of tea. The Buckingham Palace workman was visiting to dismantle a desk when an unexpected person offered him a brew. Speaking on Channel  documentary Secrets of the Royal Palaces, Royal Upholsterer Kevin Andrews, who worked for the late Queen Mother, explained what happened. He said: “A builder was dismantling a desk so he could not see who was making the offer when the ladyaposs voice asked himhe would like a cup of tea.”  Without realising it was the Queen herself who answered, he is said to have replied: “Yeah. In a mug. Two sugars. Builderaposs tea. “I donapost want any of that nonsense I had the last time I was here, all that fine china and all that saucer stuff.” Without saying anything, the Queen dropped off his cup of tea on the table, and by the time he went to pick it up the builder could only look on as he saw her walking away. The Queen is likely to have found the encounter funny, as she is known for her humour and good nature when she meets oblivious people. Like the time a hapless group of tourists once bumped into the Queen walking around her Balmoral estate - but didnapost recognise her. The monarch was out for a low-key walk in tweeds and a headscarf, something she likes to do when she gets the chance.  One of her former protection officers has revealed the -year-old likes to slip under the radar when possible. Richard Grfin claims that once a group of American tourists failed to recognise her.Speaking to The Times, Richard said the Queen didnapost want to blow her cover at the time.She went along with the tourists as they questioned whether she lived in the area, replying that she had a house nearby. When they asked hersheaposd ever met the Queen, all she said was No, but this policeman has, gesturing towards Mr Grfin. Richard - who worked closely with the monarch for more than  years - said the group then moved on, having no idea who theyaposd just met. title: salt baes guests who spent
story: Salt Baes guests who spent £, on meal say they were treated like babiesThe restaurant Nusr-Et landed on Londons streets in September and shocked guests with their extravagant prices, including an £ golden steak and £ gold burgerSalt Baes London restaurant Nusr-Et opened in September Image: Gamma-Rapho via Getty ImagesByAlexandra Bullard:,  Dec | commentsDiners at Salt Baeaposs London restaurant Nusr-Et have claimed they were treated like babies after forking out on eye-wateringly expensive food. Nusr-Et landed on Londonaposs streets in September and shocked guests with their extravagant prices, including an £ golden steak and £ gold burger.One furious guest was not too happy with his visit, saying that the staff treated them like babies, My London reports.Taking to TripAdvisor, the visitor started off by saying: The food is very average. We had a Nusret special, kafes, baklava, onion flower, giant tomahawk, four cocktails, water and kunefe. For two people we spent just shy over £,. An eye watering amount for what would be a £ meal. I would describe the level of cooking as basic.  Waiters were friendly but also a bit of a gimmick they were making annoying sounds when they were cutting our baklava. We felt we were treated like babies. He ended his review with: I guess this place is more for the elite that are on a completely dferent social hierarchy. Another angry visitor on TripAdvisor said after his meal: Food is absolutely average, at exceptional prices. Very disappointing canapost say I could be tempted backit was free. However, lots of guests have left generally positive reviews online. One person said: Food was fantastic, the nusret Stilton Burger was cooked to perfection. The staff was welcoming and friendly and looked after us. The overall experience at this restaurant was fantastic.  Another * review said: At the present time it’s the best meat restaurant in London. Excellent presentation, flavourful, succulent, delicious meat, attentive and quick to take care service. The steaks at Salt Baeaposs steakhouse cost £ - and their signature giant tomahawk steak, thataposs coated in gold leaf, racks up an incredible £, bill. Despite the heavy price tag, the London outpost has been quite the celeb magnet over the past few months.Famous faces such as David Beckham, Wayne Rooney and Gemma Collins have all splashed cash on the ludicrously expensive steaks.However, some critics have condemned the restaurantaposs tacky interiors and many guests are outraged at how expensive the menu is. title: shocking pictures show overflowing bins
story: Shocking pictures show overflowing bins and rooms filled with litter inside hospitalThe images were taken by a -year-old patient who said she was left "on her hands and knees cleaning the floor of her room" after she was left in "revolting conditions"A hospital trust has apologised to a patient for the revolting conditions on a mental health ward Image: MEN MEDIAByHelena VestyKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsA hospital trust has apologised to a patient for the revolting conditions on a mental health ward after they revealed overflowing bins, blocked sinks and kitchens littered with filth.The -year-old patient told the Manchester Evening News she was left on her hands and knees cleaning the floor of her room on the Medlock ward of the Moorside Unit at Trafford General Hospital, which cares for  people.The mum-of-three was admitted on Tuesday evening, but said she was led to a ward she claims was disgusting, and to a bedroom that had not been cleaned since the last patient was there. Greater Manchester Mental Health Trust bosses have since personally apologised to the patient after the conditions were revealed. “The linen hadn’t even been changed from the previous patient, it was all still there,” the patient said. “They had to hurriedly sort it all. I asked the nurse ‘are you going to wipe it down ’ And she said ‘yeah, I’ll do that’. She did but she said ‘oh, we didn’t realise the sink was blocked in here, I’ll flag it as urgent’.  “I had to sweep my bedroom myself because the floor was so filthy with bits on it. I asked for a dustpan and brush, got a load of disinfectant wipes. I got on my hands and knees and wiped the floor down. I don’t want to touch anything because it’s revolting. “ But after  hours the sink still had not been cleaned, meaning she went to used the communal bathroom to wash instead, only to find yet more squalor. When I went to have a wash in the bathroom, because I couldn’t in my room with the sink being blocked, I couldn’t even put my soap and towel down because I didn’t want them to touch anything,” she continued. “The bathroom was so filthy. There’s only three toilets - one of them is blocked and the other two have no toilet paper in them. “You’re limited to what you can do, really. “The basic human rights of going to the toilet, for example - I’m having to go round looking for hand towels to use as tissue because I need to use the toilet. It shouldn’t be like that.”  The kitchen was not much better, she added, as the bins were overflowing. “I thought, ‘I’ll go and get a cup of tea’, I went to put my teabag in the bin and the bins were overflowing onto the floor,” she said. “A staff member told me to ‘just throw it in’, I told them ‘this is disgusting, just shocking that people are being left like this’.” The patient, from Urmston, Greater Manchester, began fearing that her mental health would regress because of the conditions. “It’s ironic but it’s actually not good for my mental health to be here - you can’t go to the toilet, you can’t have a shower, you can’t have a wash to feel clean,” she explained. “It’s absolutely harming my recovery.  “I think they get away with it because they think no one is going to listen to the mentally ill. They can give us conditions that are not worthy of criminals and we just have to accept them, there’s little we can do about it.” After the M.E.N. approached the trust with the pictures, the patient says cleaning staff attended the ward to mop her room and unblock the sink on Wednesday, November . A spokesperson for Greater Manchester Mental Health Trust indicated that staff are unsure how the conditions deteriorated - and an investigation has been launched to find out. Andrew Maloney, Greater Manchester Mental Health Trust deputy chief executive, told the paper the pictures shown of the ward fall way below the standards of the environment that we would expect anyone to experience. He added: “The immediate action that has been taken to recty that issue provides us with assurances that it has been taken seriously and appropriately. “This is largely an isolated incident but one that we do need to learn from in the context of our CQC standards.  “We had already committed to just under £m of investment in the Moorside service, and those works have started now on site, with a complete refurbishment of all the bedroom areas. “Nonetheless, no matter what the environment is, it’s really important that we maintain high standards of cleanliness. “It’s everybody’s responsibility to make sure those environments are maintained to that high level.” One trust boss attended the ward to personally apologise on behalf of the mental health service. Now, trust chiefs say they will be carrying out quality spot checks and a quality of care programme where we scrutinise certain metrics across in patient and community services teams. In the week after arriving to scenes of squalor, the patient said “every day teams of people are turning up with clipboards doing audits, inspections, asking the patientsthere were any problems, the bathrooms smell of bleach”. She added: “I’ll give them credit they are really making the effort! If [we] hadn’t told the story, who knows  I had the head of the trust come to see me and personally apologise, she was respectful and really lovely.” The pictures of the ward follow an unannounced inspection in September by the Care Quality Commissiondue to on-going concerns about the safety of services and “the safety of people using the services”. Though the trust holds onto its ‘good’ rating, red flags were raised over staffing levels after the inspection of eight wards on five of the trust’s seven sites Brian Cranna, the CQCaposs head of hospital inspection said: “There wasn’t always enough nursing and support staff on duty, although where the trust identied signicant staff shortages, they’d put contingency plans in place. It was worrying that permanent staff didn’t always feel safe when bank and agency staff were used as they didn’t always have the relevant training to give supportan incident occurred.” On the CQC report, Ms Green has said: The inspection team found several positive aspects of care including how well staff managed risks and followed best practice, how they protected patients from abuse and knew how to report it, and ease of access to clinical information.We accept there are areas for improvement such as levels of qualied staff on wards, which many NHS trusts are struggling with, however we have strong contingency plans in place to ensure we remain safely staffed.Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Care Quality CommissionHospitalsHuman rightsMental healthPublic servicesTea" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and rd parties based on our understanding. You can unsubscribe at any time. title: tesco shopper left stitches after
story: Tesco shopper left in stitches after finding grim note stuck to dressTikTok user Billie, , claims she was about to try on the dress when she saw the note on it and put it back quickly on a rack at a Tesco Extra in West Durrington, West SussexBillies video of finding the note has gone viral on TikTok Image: billiecait TikTokByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsA Tesco shopper was left in stitches after allegedly finding a dress at the supermarket with a note that said it “smells”. TikTok user Billie, , claims she was about to try on the dress when she saw the note on it and put it back quickly. The message read: “Smells been sprayed with Febreze.” She posted the video of where she picks up the red polka dot dress and shows the unfortunate label, and it has now been seen more than , times. Billie said she had been shopping at the West Durrington Extra store with her sister and said that finding the note had given them a “laugh”. One social media user gave an explanation for what could have happened while others also found the side of it. The person claimed: Itaposll be aand theyaposve put that note on to say they think itaposs been worn, but itaposs been put out by accident. Billie replied: Gave me a laugh either way. Another person joked: Nothing a bit of Febreze canapost help. One question remained whether the dress did smell as Billie said she didn’t want to find out.  A spokesperson for Tesco told the Sun they had no record of any clothing being put back onto the shop floor with such a label, and that items which are not in good condition are removed from the shop floor. While unpleasant it wasnapost as bad as another Tesco shopper last month who found one of the most lethal spiders on the planet hanging out in a UK supermarket fruit aisle, a shopper claimed.Customer Adam Shepherd claims he discovered a cocoon with a spideraposs leg coming out” stuck to a bunch of bananas at the supermarket’s Lottbridge branch. Adam took a photo of what appears to be the deadly stowaway before, he said, he handed the contaminated bunch of bananas to staff for disposal.Adam then shared the photo to Facebook, where users identied it as a Brazilian wandering spider, or banana spider.Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TescoViral" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: wonky christmas tree resembling leaning
story: Wonky Christmas tree resembling Leaning Tower of Pisa leaves locals in stitchesA wonky Christmas tree in Gosport has left locals in fits of giggles after they say it resembles the Leaning Tower of Pisa thanks to its jaunty angleThe tree, covered in blue and white lights with red baubles, appeared to mimic the Leaning Tower of Pisa with Gosport residents, Hants, jokily posing aspropping it up Image: The News, Portsmouth FacebookByKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsItaposs officially December, meaning the countdown is on for Christmas and towns up and down the country are getting into the festive spirit.But one townaposs attempt to get into the mood has been met with giggles from locals, after a Christmas tree was installed at a wonky angle.The tree, covered in blue and white lights with red baubles, appeared to mimic the Leaning Tower of Pisa with Gosport residents, Hants, jokily posing aspropping it up. Jan Richardson, who lives in the area, said she saw it being put up while gales were blowing due to Storm Arwen. She said: I watched the tree being taken off the lorry the other night and they had a dreadful time with the wind.  The installation of the festive decorations has not been smooth sailing as the townaposs first tree was damaged in transit.Carol Whyte commented on Facebook : They had only one job to do.Gemma Shepherd added that it looked aposlike her treeapos. After locals pointed out the problems with the the festive fir it has now been aposstraightenedapos. Graham Burgess, leader of Gosport Borough Council, said: I believe the tree was straightened. I was told it was at an angle, the contractors came back - I do know that they were doing things to it.We have delivered again in the sense of providing Christmas decorations despite the situation weaposre in at the moment with the pandemic.Like many areas across the UK, Gosport cancelled the Christmas lights switch on this Saturday due to the storm which ripped through the country leaving thousands without power for days. This tree isnapost the first to be met with laughs this festive season. Shoppers in Glasgow were left in stitches after the saddest Christmas tree ever was put on display - complete with equally depressing metal fencing around it.Locals in Springburn had a good laugh at the expense of the small tree which was spotted outside a closed-down corner shop over the weekend, the Daily Record reported.This rather sad looking specimen hasnapost even been decorated - making it look very naked in among the festive celebrations.And in Grimsby, a national embarrassment of a Christmas was taken down after locals were less than impressed. The ft cone-shaped articial tree in the town cost North East Lincolnshire Council more than £,. Locals were baffled when the festive decoration was installed in Riverhead Square on Thursday and several people complained about it, with a resident claiming they had a bigger tree in their house.A person said: That is so embarrassing. Itaposs an insult to Grimsby. title: children paid almost 3m after
story: Children to be paid almost £m after pregnant mum shot dead by police SHE called forCharleena Lyles, , was shot dead by two police who responded to her call in which she was reporting a burglary - with medical examinations finding she was hit by seven bulletsCharleena Lyles was killed by Seattle police officers on th June  Image: NewsflashByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Dec | comments Four children are to be paid almost £million after their pregnant mother was shot dead by police who she called to report a burglary.The City of Seattle has agreed to pay . million to the children of Charleena Lyles. The -year-old mum died on th June  after calling police for help.Two officers responded to the call and, according to their report, evidence at the scene pointed towards the fact that the crime had been staged.They described how Charleena took out a kne as she stood in her kitchen. They both shot at her and she received seven bullets and died from her injuries.  She was pregnant at the time and her death sparked outrage and protests. Her sister Monika Williams was reported as saying: Why couldnapost they have Tased her  They could have taken her down. I could have taken her down. The court heard how Charleena was a victim of domestic violence and had a history of suffering with mental health issues. Her children, aged between five and , filed a wrongful death civil lawsuit, which was planned to go to trial in February of next year.  However, on th November, a settlement of USD . millionwas reached after a -and-a-half-hour session overseen by a judge. The children, two of whom have special needs, are now in the care of the victimaposs aunt, who is in the process of adopting them. The Seattle Police Department wrote in an online statement: We hope that this tragic case continues to serve to drive momentum towards comprehensive, holistic reform of all systems that meet at the intersection of public health and public safety. title: rare deep sea monster described
story: Rare deep-sea monster described as stuff of nightmares washes up on beachThe anglerfish, also known as the footballfish, lures in its prey with a modied dorsal ray attached to its head, which uses bioluminescent light to attract potential foodByMirror:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA man who found a rare creature with spiky looking teeth on a beach has described it as being “the stuff of nightmares”. Calornia man Jay Beiler was walking along Glider Port beach in San Diego on November  when he came across the creature, which he initially thought was a jellyfish. But on closer inspection, he realised it was a rare type of fish.Speaking to NBC San Diego, Mr Beiler said the creature was the “stuff of nightmares”.“Mouth almost looked bloody!” he added. The creature has since been identied as a footballfish, a type of anglerfish, a bony fish known for their characteristic mode of predation.  The anglerfish lures in its prey, other fish, with a modied dorsal ray attached to its head, which uses bioluminescent light to attract potential food. According to the Calornia Academy of Sciences, the species lives in the Pacic Ocean at depths of , to , feet. At this depth they are not exposed to sunlight, hence the need for other means to draw in prey. It is not known exactly how this specimen of fish made its way from the depths of the ocean, to the beach.  Mr Beiler documented his unusual find by snapping a few images of the creature, which he called “fearsome”.Social media users were both intrigued and put off by the fish, which one Facebook user called “mean-looking”.“And this is exactly why I stay away from the ocean,” another man wrote. One person suggested the fish’s appearance was a “bad omen”, possibly suggesting a climate event or other kind of natural disaster was incoming. Another person commenting on Mr Beiler’s find on Facebook simply called it “scary looking”. Ben Frable, from Scripps Research, told NBC  the fish could have come to the surface due to underwater topography. The find was a rare one, he said, and offered scientists “valuable” information on the species, given how scarce sightings were.
